This thread is for the growth of artists and those who draw for fun. If you're going to give critique, please do it constructively. Rude or blunt critiques won't help anybody.

Requesters are free to request what they wish, but avoid bumping your request every half hour as it's only going to put people off; try giving it a few hours or more.

Please provide references in ONE image, especially when requesting something outside of the Pokémon universe. If you request something from the old Drawthread or a separate thread, COPY & PASTE the actual request instead of posting a link.

Also, be mindful that requests are done at the discretion of the artists, not on a first come first serve basis.

Please remember to save any piece of art you like from these threads, as we may never know when the archive will start deleting images again. Artists can and are recommended to post their works on other outlets for archival purposes.

You know, the Kennyspam brings up an interesting proposition as to why Kenny is so completely taken aback by Goh being Dawn’s partner in the fanfic.
I wonder if he acknowledged that Dawn was likely to end up with Ash after his battle with him, considering she specifically said in her letter that she chose to go on to the League to cheer him on.
So with that in mind and having the nagging possibility that Dawn has likely hooked up with the boy she’s traveled around Sinnoh with, can you really blame his reaction when Dawn’s partner for the doubles contest isn’t any other coordinator, isn’t Ash because she might be his girlfriend, but some literal who he’s never, ever met before, and actually unlike Ash, has never even participated in, let alone been in a contest before?
I think it’s an interesting prospect to consider his initial reaction to Goh. Then there’s Ursula manipulating him afterwards as well to fuel the fire.

>>52709597
Every Pokemon has a Tera type. When you Terastallize a Pokemon, its type changes to that Tera type. It will still get STABS for its original type(s), plus a new STAB for the Tera type. If its Tera type matches one of its original types, then STAB for that type is boosted to 2x instead of 1.5x. Additionally, all Pokemon can learn the 80BP move Tera Blast, which changes its type to match your Tera type when you're Terastallized.

Effectively it's like Protean/Conversion and Hidden Power combined into one. You can use it offensively to boost a damage type, or use it defensively to eliminate or minimize weaknesses. For instance, an Ice-type can Terastallize to something with more resistances or less weaknesses, like Ghost (for Fighting-types) or Steel (for Rock-types).

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52709597
Every Pokémon has a Tera Type in addition to their regular type(s). In-game this usually matches one of the types they already have, but eventually you can change it to whatever you want.
The Tera Type doesn't do anything until you Terastalize. You can Terastalize once per battle (in-game you have to recharge it at a Pokémon Center), any Pokémon can Terastalize, they don't need to hold an item or anything. It activates at the start of the turn and changes the Pokémon's type(s) to its Tera Type.
The benefit of this is that you gain the Tera Type as a new STAB and are treated as that Type for defense, AND you don't lose the STAB on your original typing. If your Tera Type is the same as a Type you already are, then the STAB bonus goes from 1.5x to 2x damage. So a Tera Fire Charizard would do 33% more damage with Flamethrower and take less damage from Rock, but it would also lose its Ground immunity. It's also important to note that Pokémon stay Terastalized for the whole battle, even after they switch out.
Hidden Power is more or less replaced with Tera Blast, which by default is an 80BP Normal-type move but when you Terastalize it changes to match the Pokémon's Tera Type, and ALSO becomes either physical or special depending on which stat is higher.

In competitive people tend to use it to shore up a Pokémon's weaknesses instead of just stacking on more damage, but it depends on the Pokémon. A lot of the controversy comes from the idea that it makes offensive Pokémon harder to check - Gyarados can use Tera Ground to turn its 4x Electricity weakness into an immunity and benefit from STAB Earthquakes, for example - and getting one "free" turn from a super-effective hit becoming a resisted one can swing a whole battle.
It's undeniably more balanced and complex than any of the battle gimmicks before it, it has real potential downsides and trade-offs but that just makes it harder to predict and compfags hate that.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52709597
One Pokemon per battle can change their type and gain a new STAB.
For example, if Charizard's tera type is Grass, then terastalizing Charizard turns it into a mono-Grass type with all of the weaknesses and resistances of a mono-Grass type.
And it gets STAB on Fire, Flying, and Grass moves.

If you terastalize a Pokemon into one of its own original types, that STAB becomes 2x instead of 1.5x.
So if Charizard's tera type was Fire, it would become mono-Fire, losing the weaknesses, resistances, and immunity from Flying.
And it gets 2x STAB on Fire moves while keeping the 1.5x STAB on Flying moves.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52709904
It's the truth.
Mega Evolution doesn't fundamentally change the game. A mega is just a stronger Pokemon that can't hold an item.
Z-moves don't fundamentally change the game. They're just a stronger 5th move with 1 PP that comes at the cost of holding an item.
Dynamax does change the game, but there's no downside to using it beyond "If I use it now, I can't use it later".

Terastal has strong potential benefits, like resisting or being immune to a move that would normally OHKO you to get an extra hit in, or getting a power boost on a move to take out a problematic opponent, but it's also possible to choke, terastal at the wrong moment, and lose the game because of it.

posts.name: Anonymous

>>52712802
>Is the solo content interesting?
It's pretty much the original storylines you find in the console games because it uses the ROMs. In addition, the AI will be much smarter; for example, they won't use a lightning type attack if you're immune to it and might choose to switch out instead. Post-game trainer and gym rebattles get scaled up after beating the Elite Four of that region.

>Is it easy to raise a team for PvP?
It really depends on how you go about it. Most people choose to start in Kanto because it's the fastest region to beat and has access to all the EV training spots.

>Is there a point to playing this over a normal console Pokémon game?
If you want to play classic Pokémon regions without having to switch games, you might want to try this instead. You can play it on any Android device, which is convenient if you don't feel like getting a Nintendo. I personally play on my tablet and it feels like the same portable console game with a bigger screen.

>>52698976
2 stage Bug/Fighting Pokemon based on Kendo. The 3 main colours of the design would be Dark Green, a woody kinda brown and Navy Blue. Its a pretty half baked idea i came up with on the train but I thought it was neat

The first stage would be called Webogu (Like Web and Bogu like the armor) and would be a little spider mon. It would be a good mix of cute and tough. It intimidates its enemies by leaning back on 6 of its legs and showing its underside. Webogu purposely make their underside intimidating by draping thread to look like the cage on a kendo mask and smear berry juice to make big red eyes. It regularly collects sticks to train with as if they were swords, practicing swinging techniques

The second stage would be called Shinaider (Shinai like the sword and der being the last part of spider). Its body is a dark green (although mostly obscured by its legs circling it) and stemming from that body are 6 legs that look like shinai and 2 front legs that are holding shinai like swords with webbing wrapped around the handles. Its head has become more like the mask design from its underside in the previous evolution, although its hard to make out much of the physical details besides the red eyes. It also has those navy flaps that are Incorporated into traditional kendo armor near its neck as some added armor. It loves to spend its free time training, although it can be detrimental to team efforts. Shinaider are hard to get to work in a team at first but once they find their group they are loyal for life

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>Shitty art
Yeah yeah I know I'm no Picasso, but I had fun making these.
I've been making my own region based off of the Great Lakes region and this is one of the starters.

I knew that I wanted to make a pokémon based off of Mishipeshu. I thought about making it the pseudo-legendary but eventually decided to make it a starter instead. I actually really like this fakemon, even if the art is bad. Starts off as a cute little cat, evolves into a cat with a club for a tail with a vague sports theme. And the final evo has a sort of football theme. Throwing things.

I'm just not sure if the line should be Water/Steel or Water/Fighting.

>>52698976
>No paradox mons from Gens 6, 7 or 8

Let's fix that.

>Silent Sun (Electric/Psychic)
Past Paradox Heliolisk. Basically "dino-ified" and the frill becomes more spiky and hard like a ceratopsid. Gains horns to match. Still bipedal but much bulkier and tougher with a slight back fin added down its spine and tail. Uses its multiple sails to silently collect solar energy during the day that it uses to stay warm and power up at night. It meditates while doing this hence the Psychic type.

>Drain Tongue (Bug/Ghost)
Past Paradox Ribombee. It is now more drab colored with wings more similar to a moth. It has a long proboscis, similar to its first stage. Its face and body are even more feminine, however, with a longing and sultry expression. The scarf has become a body sash of some sort, to sell its more "alluring" design. It draws in prey with its exotic beauty and then drains them of their fluids.

>Iron Whisper (Poison/Steel)
Future Paradox Toxtricity. Looks like the GMax form as a "normal" mon, meaning it is much smaller. The "radio towers" on its back become more of a prominent feature and turn into metal towers. The head resembles Toxel's more. It has a metal plate across its lower face, preventing it from making sounds. It attacks with extremely high frequency ultrasonic and low frequency infrasonic sounds that rupture its foes internal organs.

>Iron Bouquet (Psychic/Dragon)
Future Paradox Bruxish. It now resembles something like a submarine with a Bruxish design. Its teeth take up most of its "face" with its eyes becoming much smaller and protected behind a "glass" dome. The head ornament thing is a far more elaborate crystal ball surrounded by metallic petals in a periscope like design. It uses its "third eye" in the crystal ball to see great distances, even across space time.

>>52703814
Sydney gets some boost with Sp Att this week, so someone who can reliably debuff that would be good. Also applies team wide paralysis before sync which fucks your regen. As a budget team I would try:
3* Marley Arcanine gives speed boost and can protect/cure the paralysis
Ghettsis with Glaciate spam can usually slow cheese one fight paired with a tank and some combination of speed booster, poisoner, sp def debuffer, or healer.
4* Viola Masquerain reduces the full team's Sp Att and can play special tank.

If you don't have the units for that, you might be able to experiment with 3* Janine Ariados which can poison and then debuff Sp Att and Speed every turn, or 3* Surge Electrode which can reduce Sp Att by 2 every turn.

>>52707993
Nintendo cannot tell you to stop if they have nowhere to deliver the message to. If you want to distribute a file with 100% chance of no one being able to do anything, create a webserver and host it exclusively via Tor or I2P. This will, however, limit who has access to your file because most people don't want to deal with this shit. You can alternatively use anonymous file hosts, uploading to them via a VPN, and reuploading whenever they get a takedown request. If you use several file hosts, you may make it cease to be worth Nintendo's time to keep playing whack a mole.

Finally, file sharing is always an option. Be aware that any time you are hosting a file off of your own PC, you leak your IP address to all of your peers. This is the case both with bittorrent and with IPFS. However, with a sufficient number of peers, it is again very fucking annoying for Nintendo to play whack a mole. They can send you a C&D order, but then everyone else with the same torrent file is capable of seeding. Once a large enough quantity of people have the file, there is nothing they can do to prevent further distribution.

Ultimately, the two keys to being successful at evading copyright law are OPSEC and persistence. Reveal as little as possible about yourself wherever possible. If you must use a name, use a pseudonym that is not in any way connected to your real name. Don't even make it one they can find through three or four hops from a google search because you used it once when you were 8, and that was on an account that you use your current email with. Make something from scratch. Be invisible and relentless.

Happy hacking.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
As a huge Pokemon fan, I have always loved the idea of sleeping with my favorite creatures by my side. There's just something so comforting and nostalgicically childhood about it. Here are a few reasons why I love sleeping with Pokemon:

They provide comfort and security: Whether it's a Snorlax snoring peacefully next to me or a Sylveon cuddling up to me for warmth, sleeping with Pokemon always feels like a hug from a loved one. Their presence brings a sense of comfort and security, especially when I'm feeling homesick or lonely.
They make for great bedfellows: Pokemon are not only cute and fluffy, but they are also incredibly loyal and affectionate. They'll happily snuggle up next to you, purring or snoring softly as they drift off to sleep. And when they wake up, they'll greet you with a cheerful chirp or a wagging tail, making you feel loved and appreciated.
They have special powers: Many Pokemon have special abilities that can help them (and you) sleep better. For example, a Jigglypuff's singing can lull you into a deep sleep, while a Snorlax's body heat can keep you warm and toasty throughout the night. Plus, some Pokemon can even sense your emotions and offer emotional support when you need it most.
They're just plain adorable: Let's face it, who doesn't love the sight of a cute little Pokemon snuggled up next to you as you drift off to sleep? Whether it's a Pikachu with its big, round eyes or a Vulpix with its fluffy tail, Pokemon are just too adorable to resist.
Overall, I love sleeping with Pokemon because they bring joy, comfort, and a sense of nostalgia to my life. Whether I'm snuggling up with a Snorlax or cuddling a Sylveon, I always feel happy and loved when I'm with my favorite creatures. So, if you're a Pokemon fan like me, I highly recommend giving it a try – you won't be disappointed!

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52710828
Now that that's out of the way, its time to talk COUNTER PICKS. Why? Because you fags always latch onto one mon you find that works and never consider anything else, then get surprised when someone comes up with something amazing.

Now, we can't really take coverage moves into account because its just way too much guesswork, so lets just talk about some notable pokemon that might be worth considering, based purely on their typing.

>Skeledirge
This is a funny pick because, thanks to Flash Fire and its typing, Cinderace without coverage moves literally CANNOT DO DAMAGE to him. In the event he does have coverage, the only problematic move is Sucker Punch, and that can (and very likely will) be completely disabled by a Bruxish or anyone with Psychic Terrain. On top of that, he's a defensive wall, meaning there's really nothing Cinderace can do to kill him at all.
But unfortunately, he also has no real way to contribute any damage to the raid. This means he'd be relegated to some kind of support role, but all he can really do is spam Mud-Slap, Helping Hand, or Leer. Not likely to be used for this reason.

>Ceruledge
Basically the same as Skeledirge, but actually more useful. The typing and Flash Fire mentioned above apply here, as well as the necessary Sucker Punch counters. Has Psycho Cut to contribute damage, but has no STAB so you'd have to make him Tera Psychic to get anything out of it. Notable utility includes Quick Guard (for Sucker Punch), Clear Smog, Swords Dance, Reflect, and Helping Hand.

(Continued)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52710840
>Armarouge
Probably the better option between the two evolutions. 100 base defense, still resists fighting even if it isn't immune, and still immune to fire. And since his fire immunity comes from an ability, he can terastallize without losing any defense. More importantly, he can actually deal big damage to Cinderace: Expanding Force + Psychic Terrain is a combo that not only deals big STAB damage, it also ensures protection from Sucker Punch. Acid Spray for even more damage, Clear Smog, Reflect, Helping Hand. No way to heal itself beyond Rest without supportmons, but this is a very strong candidate to keep an eye on. I would have one of these ready to go just to be safe, especially if Psychic Terrain, Acid Spray, and Expanding Force becomes a common strat.

>Slowbro
CHILLING WATER
Has the typing, the defense, support moves. Chilling Water will be what Mystical Fire was to Charizard. STAB Psychic, Rain Dance, Heal Pulse, Thunder Wave, Skill Swap, Helping Hand, Psychic Terrain, Nasty Plot (and Stored Power). Very, very versatile, hard to imagine him not being useful no matter the build, both solo, with randoms, and with /RCG/, but probably not the best at any one thing.

>Bruxish
Particularly notable for its ability if Cinderace has Sucker Punch. However it does also have some valuable moves: Psychic Fangs counter Court Change, Screech, Chilling Water. Rain Dance, Bulk Up, Reflect, Swords Dance, and Liquidation. Not likely to be a big deal barring Sucker Punch, but should be a perfectly useable and useful mon for this raid if you really like this ugly fish.

(Continued)

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
>>52710860
Final notes:
You might have noticed I left out Electro Ball. There's a few reasons why I think its way too unlikely he'll have this. Mainly, I think you have to think of these raids like this: what pokemon types will gamefreak WANT you to bring to these raids? When you follow that logic, it starts to make sense. There is NOTHING Cinderace can currently do to shut down Psychic types like Armarouge, as his only real coverage is Sucker Punch, which can easily be shut down by Psychic Terrain. Then we have to ask ourselves: will gamefreak give him special moves, like Electro Ball and Shadow Ball? I would argue no, as previous experience with raids like charizard suggest not only that they don't split their damage this way, but also that they wouldn't want to shut down pokemon like Slowbro or Pelipper (and really, Electro Ball would be more of an annoyance than an actual counter).

I think Cinderace will have one coverage move. It would fall in line with Charizard having 3 move types. Think of it this way: last time, gamefreak wanted you to bring Fairy types. Now, they don't want you to bring the same pokemon again. So instead, they'll give him Iron Head or Gunk Shot, to counter Fairy types. This lets them encourage people to bring Psychic or Flying(/Water) types, and the secondary 4-5 star raids will probably be pokemon of these types, like Florges and Mimikyu for Charizard. Pokemon like Armarouge are a 100% guaranteed pick for Cinderace, while pokemon like Slowbro and Pelipper can only really be annoyed by Electro Ball, a move I'm very confident he won't have.

For one shotting, since I know that's what you guys care about the most, its most likely going to be Slowbro, maybe with some kind of Fake Tears support. Setup would include Fake Tears, Psychic Terrain (bring something like Indeedee to save a moveslot and a turn), Helping Hand, Nasty Plot, and Stored Power. His stats are decent enough and the setup is big enough that it should work.

RS were solid games compared to the mess SWSH was. Emerald had much less to fix in terms of improvements and it still did a lot.

Compare Platinum to DP if you want to see the value a third version can truly add. Faster engine speed, updated graphics completely revamping the atmosphere of the region, completely different structure with some of the gyms in different order, better team building options with the revamped dex, both legendaries involved in the plot gives way to kino moments like Giratina and the distortion world. Platinum basically makes an unplayable game pretty good.

A third version done well could have made SWSH great. Instead what the DLC did is give you some decent content on top of an insufferable game you have to sit through first.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
Gen 2 didn't even have abilities, the battle system was still in very primitive form.
Revisiting Kanto was a massive disappointment. You come out in Vermillion city and they didn't even add a building where the machop was flattening the land last gen, which really sets the pace. Points of interest are mostly either simplified or removed entirely. It feels empty. I think making Kanto bigger would have been a better use of data space.
Gen 2 added the least number of new pokemon until gen VI, when they started outright recycling pokemon via mega evolution and formes.
And while it's subjective, I think a lot of them are lackluster, more so at the time because it wasn't until gens later that for example, shuckle gained the ability to deal the the highest possible damage in the game.
Most of the "features missing" next gen were either shallow and cosmetic or re-implemented in different (often better) ways.
It's not fair to compare how much better pokemon storage is, since that's a technology jump, but between that and how much better the color and sound was as well, I have a hard time seeing why there were so many people who claimed gen 2 was better given the quality of life changes alone.

I think they were just all butthurt about not being able to trade over all the pokemon they rare candied to lv 100 with the missingno glitch.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
So yeah, I like the Gen 1 cards but there was a lot wrong with the game.

1. Horribly unbalanced. The game was so unbalanced the best strategy was going with mid HP, low Attack mons and cycling your deck to get anything you want. You want an example, try the TCG for Gameboy. It's stupid easy to win once you have enough cards to do the Haymaker. Other archetypes like Energy Tans and Rainmaker really just weren't as successful.
2. For whatever reason the Gym series is almost entirely illustrated by Ken Sugimori, and it feels strange, honestly. On the one hand we got some new art that wasn't seen anywhere else, but on the other hand could you imagine if we'd gotten some badass later artists like Miki Tanaka, Tomokazu Komiya, or other extant artists like Tomoaki Imakuni had been doing card art for the set? I don't think it was a money thing either; I think they were afraid of diverging from the established style, a sin they'd come to repeat later on.
3. The US was often plagued by supply shortages. I recall specifically we never got first edition products for: Base Set, Fossil, Gym Heroes, Neo Discovery, Neo Revelation, or Neo Destiny where I lived. Yet, probably 70% of my Team Rocket cards are First Edition. I guess I got lucky that's a good set.
4. Official products were... lacking. Theme decks were 40% energy cards, you got one rare. I think that was mostly just WotC. Though i think they could have made some better products if they had a longer leash.

That said I loved the cosmo galaxy foil, miss it, wish they'd use it again. Loved the large Yellow borders, the spiky evolution boxes, and the aesthetic.

>>52704278
My theory is that it would cut profits to maintain QC standards at current production levels for US cards. I wonder if there are more cards being printed today than during Pokemania. There were a ridiculous amount of cards being printed in the late 90s but it was all the same sets and very few UPCs. Today there are so many different sets and products it's a QC nightmare.

As for Japanese cards, before pokemon they didn't have the scale or expertise to produce so many cards. In the US wotc had been doing pretty well with mtg. After japs got their shit together and with their smaller print runs it's easier to maintain QC.

It's the same reason why I think the US cards have bigger pitch sizes for foil textures. Also while vintage jap cards had terrible centering I think their card stock was much better. It was thin and durable.

posts.sub: Is there a master list of good/interesting Romhacks?

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
New games:
>Prism (Gen II)
Has two entirely new regions, bits and pieces of a third + Kanto and Johto, 60 FPS, trainer customization, and adds new mons from later generations. Infamously was so high quality that it got C&D'd by Nintendo.
>Unbound (Gen III)
Entirely new region, all modern battle mechanics and every single Pokemon up to PLA, tons of QoL features, DexNav, sidequests galore, difficulty settings, expanded post-game with multiple facilities with multiple rulesets (Battle Tower, Smogon, VGC, Inverse, you name it). Extremely high quality but be warned that there's some lame stuff in there too (DUDE WEED LMAO).
>Glazed and Gaia (Gen III)
Both have new regions and bring in some newer Pokemon, but they're a bit outdated by modern standards when compared to Unbound. Glazed in particular was similarly C&D'd like Prism.
>Vega (Gen III)
Considered the premier Japanese hack. New region, but rather than bringing in new Pokemon, it has a number of fakemon that all fit the style of actual Pokemon. Again, a bit dated but it's still pretty fondly viewed.
>Clover (Gen III)
le epic funny 4chan hack. Brand new region with an entirely brand new Pokedex, consisting of hundreds of new designs, all designed by /vp/. Comes with level caps so the game isn't a complete pushover like the normal games aren't. Your mileage will strongly vary based on how well you can stomach 4chan memes; I've seen people consider it the best hack of all time and seen people consider it complete garbage.

Revamped games:
>Red++ (Gen I)
Gen I with improved graphics, sound, Gen II features, the ability to catch every Pokemon, new areas, backported mons, Phy/Spe split, bugfixes, the works.
>Crystal Clear (Gen II)
Crystal but open world. Sounds great on paper, but the OC shit can be hard to stomach.
>Polished Crystal (Gen II)
Essentially Red++ but for Crystal.
>Drayano hacks (Gen III-VI)
Difficulty hacks that allow you to catch all Pokemon in that game's dex.

everything else is either a WIP or shit

That's a weird translation thing. It wasn't translated WRONG, exactly. The term used in Japanese is ともだち記念日. The "記念日" is a term that's usually used for anniversaries, but it's also used for some holidays. So it's not entirely clear whether it's saying "our friendship anniversary" or "Friendship Day". 4kids went with the more obvious translation.

But there's some extra context to it. The short's ending song in Japan is also called "もだち記念日" and the lyrics give a bit more insight into what it means. Basically, the song is about reminiscing about the day you met someone. Then it caps off with something to the effect of "Someone, somewhere is out there meeting their future best friend today, so that makes today Friendship Day/a Friendship Anniversary! So let's all celebrate it!"

So basically ともだち記念日 is just any day you choose to celebrate your best friend, since every day is one.

>>52709957
Pokemon remakes have always been lazy. It goes all the way back to FR/LG, where they decided to shroud all of Kanto in forests despite the theme of the region involving encroaching technology/urbanization because it meant less tilework. It fucks with location-specific themes too; Pewter city goes from being a city next to a rocky mountainside to just another fucking city surrounded by dense trees.

This trend of laziness continues with HG/SS where they missed a bunch of details from the originals, such as the loss of sleeping Pokemon from headbutt trees, Kurt no longer actually moving to his workbench to work on apricorn balls, SS Aqua trainer battles not resetting with every trip which eliminated one of the best grinding locations in the game, and music tracks playing in the wrong locations.

posts.com:
The reason that we don't have indoor Gyms, or battles in general, in this game is entirely because of the seamless transition into battles now.
Because seamless transitions require that there always be enough room in the environment around you for the battle to take place.

I said exactly this problem would happen from the very beginning when seamless transitions were going to become a thing. As cool as it might seem, and take less time, it limits level design because now everywhere has to be designed with battling in mind.

posts.name: Anonymous
posts.com:
The DLC seems to be broken up into 2 parts again. One for battling, one for story. Free update has special outbreaks for pokemon not in dex.
Part 1: Champion's Paradise
>Basicly battle frontier
>Built on the North-East side of the map. The free update starts the construction, and by the time the DLC launches, it will be finished.
>Battle tower is basically the same. The tower master is Ortega's father.
>Tempest Fleet has you battle on different ships with different weather or battle effects. The leader is a pirate woman (battle arcade but less random)
>Dusk Dungeon has you catch and battle wild pokemon, then you battle trainers. Battle factory/battle pyramid
>Royal Fort has unique gameplay, as it's like tower defense, but with pokemon battles.
>Crusade Coliseum is basically speed battling. More time is more points to use on yourself or opponents.
>All leaders are former champions that traveled to different regions at some point
Part 2: Story+Legendary Tera Raids
>Explore a new area called Area X. has fossil pokemon and other pokemon not found in dex.
>You catch new paradox mon (depending on the version, Lost legend or Lost justice) and a chameleon turtle thing that has the ability that lets it terra into any type
>Once finished, you can legendary terra pokemon

Part 1 is spring, part 2 is fall, but the timing may change due to GF working on patches.
